p:
The Ideal Weed and Disturbance Hypotheses ( Table 1) partly explain the invasion success of R. rubiginosa in Argentina
33, 38, 39 . However, the Enemy Release Hypothesis failed to explain abundance patterns â€“ natural enemies appeared equally harmful to the species in the native and introduced ranges
33 ( Table 1). By contrast, in the invasive range, anthropogenic disturbances such as logging and burning create windows of opportunities for the rose to establish, but just as importantly, disturbance events are then followed by decades of abandonment that enable the species to become abundant.
